Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2014 03:30PM Dita wrote: incredibly judgemental and also they both seem oblivious to the fact that there are hundreds of thousands of people living with metastatic cancer,  not just breast cancer. Are we not allowed a voice on social media? Are we only supposed to talk about kim kardishan's nail polish this season. Is that the best use of a tool that was designed to allow everyone to communicate? Isn't the world's obsession with material wealth and trivial matters what most complain about but when someone tries to go deeper it makes people feel uncomfortable and free to judge.   Are we that far removed from the realities of life and death that we are not allowed to talk about it publicly?

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2013 07:55AM Dita wrote: Thanks for the replies. My mets are to the spine but I was told that you can't radiate to many places on the spine because it damages bone marrow which you need if you later need chemo again down the track. Still new to this and lots learn. Teacher911 can I ask where you had your treatment and how many spots. I guess I ask because if you have one or two spots they radiate worth the intent to cure but if have any more they don't try to cure. Why is this?
Posts.Title: vero sucess anyone? Dita car2tenn

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2014 08:03AM Dita wrote: I have used sleeping pills since I've been diagnosed to help me and recently switched to melatonin which doesn't quite work as well but leaves me a lot less Groggy in the morning.  Can you see a doctor, given the circumstances sleeping pill abuse is the least of our worries and you need a good night's sleep. It might take some experimenting with the dose so you can get off to sleep OK but less Groggy in the morning. I take mine up to an hour before I go to bed so it wears off earlier. My body clock is all over the place too and I worry about sleeping my days away but we are sick and sleep is incredibly important. I have a sleep meditation mp3 that I use and it helps to slow the mind late at night so I feel more relaxed even if I can't sleep. You can Google them, there are lots on the net and some of them are free.

Posts.Title: Vow Renewal Romansma

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2014 03:57AM - edited Feb 4, 2014 04:46AM by Dita Firstly I should say that dont borrow trouble. Its easy to jump to conclusions and its most probably nothing. I had extensive bone mets at diagnosis and had no real pain. However the pain I have now is very specific,  I can touch the spot and feel pain but its not a generalized pain, its only on that spot. But since diagnosis I have been convinced of brain mets, liver mets and more bone mets and it hasn't been the case so our minds can create all kinds of problems that dont exist. You are talking some strong drugs that can cause bone aches. Speak to your onc if you are worried. Good luck rosestoses I hope its nothing
Posts.Title: Mets to Ribs & Pelvis? shelly56 lovujja

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2014 12:21AM Dita wrote: im in oz so it may be different here but I have had 8 taxol and her and perjeta. My onc is hoping that kadclya will be approved as a second line and it will probably be xeloda and tykerb after that.  My onc is very optimistic about perjeta as first line and thinks kadclya is a pretty amazing drug too. These are the first game  changers for her2 to come through in 10 years and ive heard there are more targeted treatments on the way that act in a similar way to perjeta by blocking more pathways of her2. here's hoping for success for us both on this combo and more targeted drugs soon!

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2013 10:33PM Dita wrote: sorry youre here. I have been on that combo for 8 treatments. The taxol makes you lose your hair and there is fatigue. The effect is cumulative and I started feeling fatigue from about the fifth cycle. I worked throughout but did have a few sick days towards the end as I had them up my sleeve so thought why not. The doses of chemo that they give you for stage iv are less than the early stages. Good luck, I hope you get lots of mileage out of those treatments.
Posts.Title: I am back in the club. mokenagirl Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2013 05:41PM Dita wrote: I personally would like more people to read these stage iv  threads. I think that the fact that breast cancer can be fatal and stage iv is incurable is just not common knowledge.  I sat in a support group of ebc and when I told them I was stage iv and was struggling to cope they told me to concentrate on getting well and that id feel better once my treatment had finished.  And this was from a bunch of women with breast cancer! I've also been told by another  survivior that the only people who die are those that refuse treatment.  That 90% survival rate statistic is misleading to say the least.

Posts.Title: Question about stopping Herceptin NickyJ Gloria17

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2014 01:01AM Dita wrote: Raro, no wonder you feel down.  You have been going at this a long longer than me and i am already exhausted and depressed. There is lots of good advice here about some of the little things you can do to feel better and maybe tomorrow or the next day wont be as bad as today.   One thing I did read from your email is that you would like to have more energy for your children and you dont like the fact that you feel depressed.  I dont have children (f$*king cancer) but I do feel guilty when my partner has so much more energy than me.  And I feel like I should be making more of my time here.  I cant stop those feelings but I can say that its not our fault. You and your children are together and that is the main thing.  My partner is just happy Im here, regardless whether I want to spend all day in bed or not.  Im sure your children feel the same.  They will cherish these moments with you forever. When you sit on the couch and watch TV, make sure you watch something good and that you have good quality ice cream.  I hope you feel better soon
